factoid: The count danced well.
The count knew that he danced well.
Márya Dmítrievna could not dance well.
Márya Dmítrievna did not want to dance well.
Márya Dmítrievna's enormous figure stood erect.
Márya Dmítrievna's powerful arms hung down.
Márya Dmítrievna had handed her reticule to the countess.
Only Márya Dmítrievna's stern but handsome face really joined in the dance.
The count's plump figure expressed something that in Márya Dmítrievna was expressed only in her beaming face and quivering nose.
The count charmed the spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers.
The count charmed the spectators by the agility with which he capered on his light feet.
Márya Dmítrievna produced no less impression by slight exertions.
Márya Dmítrievna's slight exertions included the least effort to move her shoulders.
Márya Dmítrievna's slight exertions included bending her arms when turning.
Márya Dmítrievna's slight exertions included stamping her foot.
Everyone appreciated Márya Dmítrievna's slight exertions given her size and habitual severity.
The dance grew livelier and livelier.
The other couples could not attract a moment's attention to their own evolutions.
The other couples did not even try to attract a moment's attention to their own evolutions.
All were watching the count and Márya Dmítrievna.
Natásha kept pulling everyone by sleeve or dress.
Natásha urged everyone to look at Papa.
Everyone never took their eyes off the count and Márya Dmítrievna.
During intervals, the count was breathing deeply.
The count waved to the musicians.
The count shouted to the musicians to play faster.
The count whirled lightly, more lightly, and yet more lightly.
The count flew around Márya Dmítrievna on his toes.
The count flew around Márya Dmítrievna on his heels.
The count turned Márya Dmítrievna around to her seat.
The count executed the final pas.
The count raised his soft foot backwards.
The count bowed his perspiring head.
The count smiled.
The count made a wide sweep with his arm.
The applause and laughter were led by Natásha.
Both partners stood still.
Both partners were breathing heavily.
Both partners wiped their faces with cambric handkerchiefs.
The count said, 'That’s how we used to dance in our time, ma chère.'
Márya Dmítrievna exclaimed, 'That was a Daniel Cooper!'
Márya Dmítrievna tucked up her sleeves.
Márya Dmítrievna puffed heavily.
In the Rostóvs’ ballroom the sixth anglaise was being danced.
The tune was played by weary musicians who blundered.
Footmen and cooks were getting the supper.
Count Bezúkhov performed a sixth stroke.
Doctors pronounced Count Bezúkhov's recovery impossible.
Count Bezúkhov made a mute confession.
Communion was administered to Count Bezúkhov.
Preparations were made for the sacrament of unction for Count Bezúkhov.
In Count Bezúkhov's house there was the bustle and thrill of suspense.
Outside the house beyond the gates a group of undertakers hid whenever a carriage drove up.
The undertakers waited in expectation of an important order for an expensive funeral.
The Military Governor of Moscow had been assiduous in sending aides-de-camp to inquire after Count Bezúkhov's health.
The Military Governor of Moscow came that evening to bid a last farewell to Count Bezúkhov.
The reception room was crowded.
Everyone stood up respectfully when the Military Governor had stayed about half an hour alone with Count Bezúkhov.
The Military Governor slightly acknowledged their bows.
The Military Governor tried to escape as quickly as possible from the glances fixed on him by doctors, clergy, and relatives.
Prince Vasíli had grown thinner and paler during the last few days.
Prince Vasíli escorted Count Bezúkhov to the door.
Prince Vasíli repeated something to Count Bezúkhov several times in low tones.
After the Military Governor had gone, Prince Vasíli sat alone on a chair in the ballroom.
Prince Vasíli crossed one leg high over the other.
Prince Vasíli leaned his elbow on his knee.
Prince Vasíli covered his face with his hand.
Prince Vasíli rose after sitting for a while.
Prince Vasíli looked at Count Bezúkhov with frightened eyes.
Prince Vasíli went with unusually hurried steps down the long corridor leading to the back of the house.
Prince Vasíli went to the room of the eldest princess.
Those in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous whispers.
Whenever anyone went into or came from Count Bezúkhov's room, people grew silent.
People gazed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at Count Bezúkhov's door.
Count Bezúkhov's door creaked slightly when opened.
An old priest said, 'The limits of human life ... are fixed and may not be o’erpassed,' to a lady.
The lady had taken a seat beside the old priest.
The lady was listening naïvely to the old priest's words.
The lady asked, 'I wonder, is it not too late to administer unction?'
The lady added the old priest’s clerical title in her question.
The lady acted as if she had no opinion of her own on the subject.
The old priest replied, 'Ah, madam, it is a great sacrament.'
The old priest passed his hand over the thin grizzled strands of hair combed back across his bald head.
